questions.text: All of the following are normal cardiovascular changes during pregnancy EXCEPT:

choices.text: Systolic flow murmur over the tricuspid area
Fixed split of second heart sound (S2)
Systolic flow murmur over pulmonary area

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fixed split of second heart sound (S2)

Explanation:

  • Fixed splitting of S2 is not a normal finding in pregnancy. A fixed split of the second heart sound indicates atrial septal defect (ASD) or other pathologies that delay right ventricular systole irrespective of respiration.
  • In pregnancy, there may be physiological splitting of the first heart sound. Systolic flow murmurs over the tricuspid area (Option A ruled out), over the pulmonary area (Option D ruled out), they can be there because blood flow across the walls of the heart increase. Ejection systolic murmur grade 1, grade 2, they are okay. Grade 3 or more ejection systolic murmurs, they need to be investigated. Third heart sound is physiological because of the turbulence in the rapid flow of blood across the chambers of the heart (Option B ruled out). A fourth heart sound is something that needs to be investigated,

Normal Changes During Pregnancy:

Category

Change

Description

Clinical Implication

Auscultatory Changes

Heart Sounds

• Exaggerated splitting and louder S1

• No change in aortic/pulmonary S2

• Loud S3 

All are normal findings on auscultation during pregnancy

Murmurs

• Common: soft systolic ejection murmurs

• Occasional: soft diastolic or continuous (mammary) murmurs

Typically benign; must differentiate from pathological murmurs

questions.text:
A 30-year-old primigravida at 24 weeks of gestation presents with concerns about several skin changes. She describes a dark vertical line running down her abdomen, dark patches on her face, and pinkish lines on her thighs. She denies any itching, pain, or other systemic symptoms. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she is not on any medications apart from prenatal vitamins.

What is the most likely explanation for these skin changes?

choices.text: Linea Nigra, Chloasma (Melasma), and Striae Gravidarum
PUPPP (Pruritic Urticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Linea Nigra, Chloasma (Melasma), and Striae Gravidarum

Explanation:

During pregnancy, various physiological skin changes can occur due to hormonal influences:

  • Linea Nigra: A dark vertical line running down the abdomen due to increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone.

  • Chloasma (Melasma): Hyperpigmented patches on the face, often called the "mask of pregnancy," due to hormonal changes and sometimes exacerbated by sun exposure.

  • Striae Gravidarum: Pinkish or purplish lines, commonly known as stretch marks, which appear on the abdomen, thighs, or breasts due to the stretching of the skin.

PUPPP (Option B) typically presents with intensely itchy, red, raised patches that often begin in the stretch marks of the abdomen and can spread to the thighs, buttocks, and arms, but not with pigmentation changes.
 

Pemphigoid gestationis (Option C) is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically begins with itchy urticarial papules and plaques around the umbilicus.


Atopic Eruption of Pregnancy (Option D) Presents with eczematous lesions or pruritic folliculitis, usually without the pigmentation changes described.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in her first trimester visits her obstetrician with complaints of breast tenderness and swelling. The physician explains that these changes are common during pregnancy. Which of the following breast changes is most characteristic of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Development of Montgomery's tubercles


Explanation:

Montgomery's Tubercles become prominent during pregnancy. 

Breast changes in pregnancy:

  • The breast changes are evident between 6 and 8 weeks.
  • There is enlargement with vascular engorgement evidenced by the delicate veins visible under the skin (Option C ruled out) 
  • The nipple and the areola (primary) become more pigmented, especially in dark women (Option A ruled out) 
  • Montgomery's Tubercles become prominent.
  • Thick yellowish secretion (colo­strum) can be expressed as early as 12th week.
  • Breasts become more sensitive (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: During pregnancy there is increased demand for calcium, as the fetus accures about 30 g of calcium for building its own skeleton. Which of the following maternal changes is responsible for meeting this increased demand?

choices.text: Increased production of cortisol from the adrenal glands
Enhanced intestinal calcium absorption due to increased calcitriol levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Enhanced intestinal calcium absorption due to increased calcitriol levels

Explanation:

During pregnancy, calcitriol levels increase, enhancing intestinal calcium absorption to support fetal skeletal mineralization.

  • Decreased serum calcium levels could indicate increased calcium demand or issues with absorption.
     

During pregnancy, cortisol levels increase, but this is associated with increased free cortisol levels, not decreased serum calcium levels. (Option A)

TBG levels increase during pregnancy, affecting thyroid hormone levels, but this change does not directly impact serum calcium levels (Option B)

Initially, PTH levels may decrease in early pregnancy, but they rise later due to increased calcium demand. Decreased PTH would not cause decreased serum calcium levels. (Option C)

ENDOCRINE CHANGES IN PREGNANCY

INCREASE

DECREASE

UNCHANGED
  • Prolactin
  • Growth Hormone
  • ACTH
  • Cortisol
  • Aldosterone
  • Testosterone
  • Calcitriol
  • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG)
  • Total T4
  • Total T3
  • hCG
  • Human placental lactogen (hPL)
  • Insulin
  • PTH
  • Calcitonin
  • FSH
  • LH
  • DHEAS (Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate)
  • Free T3
  • Free T4
  • Vasopressin (ADH)

questions.text: A 28-y/o woman at 32 weeks gestation complains of occasional indigestion, bloating and painful bulges around the anus with occasional rectal bleeding. Her LFTs reveal double the nonpregnant levels of serum ALP, with normal levels of ALT and AST and normal bile acid levels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
​​​​​Correct Answer: A) Physiological changes of pregnancy

Explanation:

  • During pregnancy, Estrogen stimulates ALP production in the placenta, doubling the levels. The absence of elevated ALT and AST supports this diagnosis over other pathological conditions.
  • Hemorrhoids causing painful bulges around the anus with occasional rectal bleeding are common during pregnancy. They are caused by constipation (d/t atonicity of gut) and elevated pressure in rectal veins below the level of the enlarged uterus.
  • Heartburns, indigestion, and bloating are also changes present in a normal pregnancy.

Other GI changes in pregnancy:

  • The risk of peptic ulcer disease is reduced.
  • Gallbladder atonicity (progesterone effect) increases the risk of stone formation

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (Option B) typically presents with profound elevation of ALT and AST levels, along with coagulopathy and hepatic encephalopathy. It is a serious condition that requires immediate intervention and often occurs in the third trimester.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) (Option C) is characterized by pruritus and elevated bile acids, with or without elevated transaminases. It commonly presents in the third trimester and is associated with adverse fetal outcomes. While ICP can cause elevated ALP and GGT due to cholestasis, the absence of elevated ALT and AST makes ICP less likely in this scenario.

Acute viral hepatitis (Option D) typically presents with markedly elevated ALT and AST levels, along with symptoms such as jaundice and malaise.

questions.text: A 28-y/o woman in her 32nd week of gestation presents with urinary frequency. Which of the following physiological changes in the urinary system during pregnancy is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increased renal blood flow

 

Explanation:

Increased renal blood flow during pregnancy ensures adequate perfusion of the kidneys, supporting increased GFR by 50% and increased urine production by 50-75% to accommodate maternal and fetal metabolic needs.

Decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) (Option A): Pregnancy is associated with an increased GFR due to increased renal blood flow and hormonal changes.

Decreased bladder capacity (Option C) : Bladder capacity is not decreased in pregnancy.

Increased intraureteral tone (Option D): In pregnancy, there is ureteral dilatation;the smooth muscles of the ureter are relaxing. So there is no increased ureteral tone in pregnancy.

Kidney

Ureter

Bladder

Dilatation of ureters, renal pelvis, and calyces

Ureters become atonic due to high progesterone

Marked congestion and hypertrophy of the wall

Renal plasma flow increases by 50–75% (max at 16 weeks)

Dilation and stasis, especially on the right side

Increased micturition at 6–8 weeks, subsides after 12 weeks

GFR increases by 50%, reducing plasma creatinine, BUN, uric acid

Elongation and kinking of ureters

Late pregnancy leads to increased frequency due to pressure

Tubules fail to reabsorb glucose, uric acid, amino acids, and vitamins

Muscle hypertrophy in the pelvic part

Stress incontinence may occur in late pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following changes in the respiratory system is NOT typically observed during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Decreased minute ventilation

Explanation:

Minute ventilation (total volume of air breathed in one minute) increases during pregnancy to ensure sufficient oxygen delivery to the mother and fetus. This increase is a result of

  • Enhanced Respiratory drive d/t stimulation of Progesterone
  • Low expiratory reserve volume
  • Compensatory Respiratory alkalosis
     

Increased tidal volume (Option A): During pregnancy, tidal volume typically increases to meet the increased oxygen demand of the mother and fetus.
 

Decreased functional residual capacity (FRC) (Option B): FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation. During pregnancy, the uterus enlarges, causing the diaphragm to be elevated, leading to a decrease in FRC.
 

Respiratory rate unchanged (Option D): Respiratory rate may remain relatively unchanged during pregnancy due to hormonal changes, particularly the increase in progesterone, which affects respiratory drive.

RESPIRATORY PARAMETERS IN NORMAL PREGNANCY

INCREASES

DECREASES

UNCHANGED
  • Inspiratory Capacity
  • Tidal Volume
  • Minute Ventilation
  • Peak Expiratory Flow Rates
  • Oxygen Consumption
  • Airway Conductance
  • Blood pH
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)
  • Total Pulmonary Resistance
  • Plasma Bicarbonate Levels
  • Total Lung Capacity
  • Respiratory Rate
  • Lung Compliance
  • Forced or Timed Vital Capacity
  • Maximum Breathing Capacity

questions.text: Which factor contributes significantly to the hypercoagulable state observed in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increased levels of fibrinogen

Explanation:

  • Fibrinogen levels increase by 50% during pregnancy. This increase promotes clot formation and contributes to the hypercoagulable state.
  • All clotting factors increase except 11 and 13

 

Decreased levels of antithrombin III (Option A): While antithrombin III levels may decrease slightly during pregnancy, it is not the primary factor contributing to the hypercoagulable state.

Elevated levels of protein S (Option C): Protein S levels decrease during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state.

Decreased levels of Factor VIII (Option D): Factor VIII levels increase during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state along with other clotting factors. Except for Factors XI & XIII, levels of all other clotting factors is increased.

Clotting Factor

Change during pregnancy

Fibrinogen

Increased

II, VII, VIII, IX, X and I

Increased

II, V, and XII

Unchanged or mildly increased

XI and XIII

Decreased

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hematological changes in pregnancy is incorrect?

choices.text: Blood volume starts to increase during the 6th week
RBC mass increases by 20-30% when compared to a non-pregnant level.
The normal albumin : globulin ratio of 1.7:1 is diminished to 1:1.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Erythrocyte sedimentation rate reduces by 50% due to decreased blood viscosity.

Explanation:
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) actually increases during pregnancy, mainly due to elevated levels of fibrinogen and globulin, and due to decreased blood viscosity caused by hemodilution.

 

Hematological changes in pregnancy:

  1. Blood Volume

1. Total Blood Volume (Option A)

Starts to increase around 6th week and peaks by 30-34 weeks of gestation

+30-50% increase

2. RBC Mass (Option B)

Increases for accommodating increased oxygen demands.

+20-30% increase

3. Hemoglobin Concentration

Decreases due to hemodilution as plasma volume increases more than RBC mass.

Decreased by 2g% near the end of term (Physiological anemia)

4. Hematocrit Levels

Decrease due to hemodilution from increased plasma volume.

From 38% (non pregnant) to 32% (pregnant)
  1. WBC and Platelets

1. White Blood Cell Count

Increases, leading to physiological leukocytosis.

-

2. Platelet Count

Slightly decreased due to increased consumption and dilution. (Gestational Thrombocytopenia)

Reduced by 0-15%

C. ESR

1. Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)

Due to elevated levels of fibrinogen and globulin, and due to decreased blood viscosity caused by hemodilution

Increased upto 4 folds

D. Blood proteins

1. Total Protein

Total plasma protein increases. Globulin increases and thus A:G  ratio decreases (Option D). 

From 180 g (nonpregnant) to 230 g at term.

Increase

Decrease

Total Blood Volume

RBC Mass

WBC Count

ESR

Total Protein

Hemoglobin Concentration

Hematocrit Levels

Platelet Count

questions.text: Which of the following adaptations describes dynamic changes in the uterus during pregnancy?

choices.text: The uterus increases in weight by approximately 50 grams by the end of the first trimester.
Uterine size remains unchanged until the third trimester when it begins to enlarge rapidly.
The capacity of the uterus increases by 500-1000 times at the end of the third trimester
Uterine size decreases progressively after the second trimester

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The capacity of the uterus increases by 500-1000 times at the end of the third trimester

Explanation:

The capacity of the uterus increases by 500-1000 times at the end of the third trimester (around 40 wks).

  • It is primarily due to the growth of the fetus, placenta, amniotic fluid, and hypertrophy of uterine tissues. By term, the uterus weighs nearly 1100 gms and has an average size of 5L.
  • During the first trimester of pregnancy, the uterus undergoes significant changes as it prepares for fetal development. On average, the uterus can weigh around 70g in a non-pregnant woman. (Option A)
  • The uterus starts to enlarge from the early stages of pregnancy and continues to grow steadily throughout all trimesters. (Option B)
  • Uterine size does not decrease during pregnancy. Instead, it continues to enlarge and grow to accommodate the developing fetus. (Option D)

questions.text: A 28 y/o primigravida, currently in her third trimester, presents to the clinic complaining of dizziness and shortness of breath, especially when lying on her back. She feels better when she shifts to her left side. What is the condition likely due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inferior vena cava compression

Explanation:

The symptoms of shortness of breath due to lying on her back imply a decreased cardiac output. It usually occurs in pregnant women due to compression of the inferior vena cava and aorta by the gravid uterus when lying in the supine position and is called Supine hypotensive syndrome.

 

It leads to reduced venous return, decreased cardiac output, and hypotension. It causes nausea, dizziness and shortness of breath. This condition is relieved by shifting to a left lateral position.
 

 

Increased uterine blood flow (Option A): does not cause the symptoms mentioned 

Increased cardiac output (Option C): The above symptoms correspond to decreased cardiac output due to IVC compression.

Increased abdominal pressure (Option D): It does not cause the above symptoms.

questions.text: All of the following changes are true during pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased mean arterial pressure (MAP)


Explanation:

During pregnancy, the mean arterial pressure (MAP) typically decreases or remains relatively stable due to the increased blood volume and decreased systemic vascular resistance. 

 

Change in Pregnancy

Reason

Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)

Unchanged

Does not increase during pregnancy; it typically decreases slightly due to decreased systemic vascular resistance despite elevated cardiac output. (Option D)

Systolic Blood Pressure

Decrease

Systemic vascular resistance decreases due to the relaxing effects of progesterone, nitric oxide, prostaglandins, and ANP, leading to lower blood pressure. (Option A)

Stroke Volume

Increase

Blood volume increases during pregnancy, increasing preload and subsequently increasing stroke volume (amount of blood pumped per heart contraction). (Option B)

Pulse Rate

Increase

Heart rate increases by about 15 beats per minute during pregnancy to support the increased cardiac output necessary for the growing fetus. (Option C)

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is evaluated by her obstetrician for routine prenatal care. She reports occasional palpitations and mild shortness of breath but has no significant past medical history. The physician explains that these symptoms can be related to normal cardiac changes in pregnancy. Which of the following is a physiological cardiac change typically observed during pregnancy?

choices.text: Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume
Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension
Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume
Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume


Explanation:
During pregnancy, the heart rate increases by up to 17%, and the stroke volume increases by up to 27%. As a result of this, Cardiac Output increases as

  • Cardiac Output = Heart Rate x Stroke Volume.

Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume (Option A): Cardiac output is not decreased, but it is increased in pregnancy

Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension (Option B): There is a decrease in systemic vascular resistance, so BP falls during pregnancy.

Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone (Option D): There is increase in heart rate during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which hormone is primarily responsible for the proliferation of the ducts in the breasts during early pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Estrogen

Explanation:

 

Estrogen plays a key role in stimulating the growth and proliferation of the ductal structures in the breasts, preparing them for milk production.

Hormone

Function

Estrogen (Option B)
  • Proliferation of the ducts and alveoli
  • Growth and branching of the ductal system, causing increased size of the breasts.
Progesterone (Option A)

Development of the alveoli in the breasts after priming by estrogen 
Prolactin (Option C)
  • Production and secretion of milk after childbirth.
  • Maintenance of effective and continuous lactation
Oxytocin (Option D)
  • Milk ejection reflex or let-down reflex during breastfeeding.
  • It causes the myoepithelial cells to contract and expel milk from the alveoli into the ducts.

questions.text: During a routine prenatal visit at 32 weeks gestation, a pregnant woman reports occasional episodes of tightening in front of her abdomen that are irregular and painless. On examination, her uterus is non-tender with no cervical changes noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Braxton Hicks contractions

 

Explanation:

Braxton Hicks contractions are irregular, painless, and usually occur as a normal part of pregnancy, especially in the later stages. They are often described as a tightening of the abdomen without cervical changes.

Feature

True Labour Pains

(Option A)

False Labour Pains

(Braxton Hicks Contractions)

Regularity

Contractions are regular, becoming closer together over time

Contractions are irregular, no consistent pattern.

Duration

Lasts longer (30-70 seconds each contraction)

Shorter duration (less than 30 seconds for each contraction)

Intensity

Increases in intensity as labor progresses

Less intense compared to true labor contractions

Location of Pain

Starts in the lower back and radiates to the abdomen

Typically felt in the front of the abdomen

Progression

Causes cervical dilation and effacement, leading to opening of the cervix

Does not cause cervical changes or dilation

Abruptio placenta (Option B) is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. It is associated with mild to severe uterine tenderness, and vaginal bleeding, and often presents with signs of fetal distress.

Uterine inertia (Option D) is characterized by inadequate uterine contractions that fail to cause cervical dilation and are associated with prolonged labor. The woman in this scenario does not present with labor or active labor contractions, making uterine inertia unlikely.

questions.text:
Match the following statements with the right option.


	
		
			
			1. Chadwick's sign
			
			
			a. Increased pulsations felt through lateral fornices.
			
		
		
			
			2. Goodell’s sign
			
			
			b. Softening of Cervix.
			
		
		
			
			3. Osiander's sign
			
			
			c. Bluish hue of the vaginal wall.
			
		
		
			
			4. Hegar's sign
			
			
			d. Abdominal & vaginal fingers oppose below the body of the uterus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1- c, 2- b, 3- a, 4- d

Explanation:

The following are the early signs of pregnancy in the 1st trimester:

Early Signs of Pregnancy

Description

Cause

Week of Pregnancy

Hegar's sign

Softening of the lower uterine segment

Increased vascularity and relaxation of the smooth muscle

6-8 weeks of gestation

Chadwick's sign (Jacquemier’s sign)

 

Bluish discoloration of the cervix and vagina

Increased vascularity in response to hormonal changes in pregnancy.

8th week

Goodell's sign

Softening of the cervix

Increased vascularization and edema.

6th week

Piskacek's sign

Asymmetric enlargement of the uterus

Lateral implantation of fertilized ovum

-

Palmer's sign

Regular and rhythmic uterine contractions

Due to increased estrogen levels, and the physiological adaptations of the uterus preparing for labor

4-8 weeks

Osiander's sign

Increased pulsations felt through lateral fornices

Increased blood flow uterus by the uterine arteries

8th-12th week

Hegar's sign:

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a type of normal cervical change during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cervical Incompetence

Explanation:

  • Cervical incompetence / cervical insufficiency is a condition where the cervix opens too early during pregnancy, usually in the 2nd trimester, without contractions or labor leading to miscarriage or preterm birth.

Cervical ripening (Option A) is a series of complex biochemical changes in the cervix mediated by hormones ( PGE2 and PGF2alpha). There is an alteration of both cervical collagen and ground substance. Ultimately, the cervix becomes soft and pliable. 

Cervical Effacement (Option B) or Shortening refers to the thinning and shortening of the cervix as it prepares for childbirth.

Cervical dilation (Option C) refers to the normal opening or widening of the cervix during labor to allow the passage of the fetus through the birth canal.

questions.text: Which of the following factors does NOT increase uteroplacental blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Angiotensin II

 

Explanation:

Angiotensin II generally causes vasoconstriction, which can reduce blood flow, including in the uteroplacental circulation.

 

 

Factor

Affect on uteroplacental blood flow

Function

Characteristics

Angiotensin II


 

Decreases (Option C)

Vasoconstriction

It constricts the uterine arteries, which reduces blood flow. It does not increase uteroplacental blood flow.

Nitric oxide (NO)



 

Increases (Option A)

Vasodilation

Relaxes smooth muscles in blood vessels, increasing blood flow to the placenta and uterus during pregnancy.

Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2)


 

Increases (Option B)

Vasodilation

Promotes relaxation of vascular smooth muscle, leading to increased uteroplacental blood flow.

Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF)


 

Increases (Option D)

Promotes angiogenesis 7 vasculogenesis

Leading to the formation of new blood vessels and increased blood flow to the uterus and placenta during pregnancy.
